unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about the deadline for filing income tax returns, especially with all the news buzzing around. It's a pretty common question, and I understand why there's confusion.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about the deadline for filing income tax returns, especially with all the news buzzing around. It's a pretty common question, and I understand why there's confusion.

unnormalised: Generally, for individuals, the last date for filing Income Tax Return (ITR) is usually 31st July of the assessment year. For example, for the financial year 2023-24, which is assessment year 2024-25, the due date was July 31st, 2024. But hey, there’s always a ‘but’ in life, right?
normalised: Generally, for individuals, the last date for filing Income Tax Return (I-T-R) is usually thirty first July of the assessment year. For example, for the financial year two thousand twenty three to two thousand twenty four, which is assessment year two thousand twenty four to two thousand twenty five, the due date was July thirty first, two thousand twenty four. But hey, there’s always a ‘but’ in life, right?

unnormalised: Sometimes, the govt. might extend the deadline, but don’t bank on it! These extensions are usually announced closer to the date, depending on circumstances. Keep an eye on news channels like NDTV or even just a quick Google search of "ITR Filing Last Date" will give you the latest updates. Usually, the income tax department will post about it @IncomeTaxIndia on X or through a press release.
normalised: Sometimes, the government might extend the deadline, but don’t bank on it! These extensions are usually announced closer to the date, depending on circumstances. Keep an eye on news channels like N-D-T-V or even just a quick Google search of "I-T-R Filing Last Date" will give you the latest updates. Usually, the income tax department will post about it at Income Tax India on X or through a press release.

unnormalised: Now, if you’re a company or require an audit, the deadline is different. It's usually 31st Oct. Again, keep checking for changes. Delaying can attract interest u/s 234A of Income Tax Act and a late filing fee u/s 234F, which can be up to Rs. 5000! No one wants that, right?
normalised: Now, if you’re a company or require an audit, the deadline is different. It's usually thirty first October. Again, keep checking for changes. Delaying can attract interest under section two hundred and thirty four A of Income Tax Act and a late filing fee under section two hundred and thirty four F, which can be up to rupees five thousand! No one wants that, right?

unnormalised: Also, a pro-tip. Try and file your ITR well before the due date, like maybe by 15th July. Last minute rushes can lead to website crashes and you might miss the deadline due to technical glitches. Plus, you'll have time to correct any mistakes.
normalised: Also, a pro-tip. Try and file your I-T-R well before the due date, like maybe by fifteenth July. Last minute rushes can lead to website crashes and you might miss the deadline due to technical glitches. Plus, you'll have time to correct any mistakes.

unnormalised: So, to summarise: Generally, it's 31/07 but always double-check with official sources. Don’t rely on hearsay from your Sharma Uncle or news you heard over chai. Get the info from the IT department directly. They usually give a final reminder around 1 week before the deadline, too.
normalised: So, to summarise: Generally, it's thirty first July but always double-check with official sources. Don’t rely on hearsay from your Sharma Uncle or news you heard over chai. Get the info from the I-T department directly. They usually give a final reminder around one week before the deadline, too.

unnormalised: Finally, remember to file accurately. Don't try and fudge numbers - its just not worth it. And if you're not confident doing it yourself, consult a CA. They’ll make sure everything is in order. Best of luck with your filing! Hope this helps clear things up.
normalised: Finally, remember to file accurately. Don't try and fudge numbers - its just not worth it. And if you're not confident doing it yourself, consult a C-A. They’ll make sure everything is in order. Best of luck with your filing! Hope this helps clear things up.
